Mark Ahlstrom wrote:

>This year I am doing my masters thesis, and want to do some research in 
>neuroevolution.  Specifically, I want to do a comparison of recurrent 
>networks and networks with plastic synapses, looking at how well they 
>scale to more complicated problems.  I've been doing my background 
>homework on the topic, but am having some trouble coming up with a 
>problem domain for an experiment to test things with.  Any suggestions 
>or advice?
>  
>
I think Ken wrote a paper on plastic synapses, is that right? - I admit 
to not reading it yet though :(

Dynamic networks are more suited to a different set of problems than 
fixed weight nets. e.g. There was an article in August's Scientific 
American about NASA scientists using adaptive neural nets to fly cripled 
aircraft, the net's architecture is fixed (from previous 
experimentation) but the network adapts by changing it's weights to 
adapt to how the aircraft has been cripled - e.g. if a plane's elevators 
aren't working the network learns to lift a plane by using the ailerons 
in unison to lift the nose.

Now you could ask the question, could a fixed weight network achieve the 
same results? That is, we could attempt to train a network against all 
the expected types of failure. If it is possible, the fixed network 
would almost certainly be more complex since it has to 'store' all of 
the different configuartions, whereaas the dynamic net just re-learns 
weight for each scenario presented. On the other hand the plane might 
crash while the net was learning, e.g. in trying to pull up it might 
initially cause the plane to fall before it is able get an error 
feedback signal which causes the weights to update. So if a fixed weight 
net could be found you would be one up on the NASA guys :)

I'm not suggesting you commandeer a plane but I'm guessing that there is 
some pretty acurate flight sim code out there somewhere.


What else? Well game playing tends to be based around built-in, 
pre-learned strategies which would be hard to learn dynamically, so I'm 
guessing that area is out. Having said that, maybe they could benefit 
from some dynamic weights, e.g. adjusting the priority of the various 
built-in strategies depending on how the game is progressing. It would 
be interesting if this sort of effect could be shown to occur.

Out of curiosity whereabouts are you studying? Austin?

Regargs,

Colin.
